text: I first had this "Old Beer" in D-Town. I believe it was a special offering after they expanded the brewery; for sure, they brewed it for their 10th birthday. Recently, I bought a growler at Kennett Square, and I poured into a pint glass. Theres a slight, sweet malt nose. Nice amber coloring with a white head (very similar to their Festbier). Expertly balanced with a strong malt presence and a bitter after bite. Has a heavy feel being a lager, but its easy going down at 5%. Cheers!

Transfer from BA review on 9-4-13-

 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer is served a lighter copper-deep amber color with a one finger white head. The head fades relatively quickly leaving a very light level of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is lighter overall, but has notes of a lightly toasted bread and a bit of a herbal hop and a light sweetness of caramel.

 Taste  The taste is very much as would be expected from the nose. It starts with a lightly roasted bready flavor mixed with a bit of caramel sweetness. The sweetness fades a bit as the taste moves on all while a herbal and slightly grassy hop taste comes to the tongue. These flavors are joined by some more light earthy flavors, to in the end, leave a rather light and crisp flavor on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is rather light and thin with a carbonation level that is rather average. The thinner body and moderate carbonation are good for the lighter flavors and create a very crisp and easy drinking brew. 

 Overall  More on the refreshing side, but a little bit low in the flavor profile which all in all makes for a nice easy drinking session brew.
big foamy head. pale yellah. smells a little like hops. yes, taste is hops poken thru. tongue gets more bitter as session moves on. fairly flat. some citrus baldness in the background.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Draft at Harrison Roadhouse. Pale yellow with a white head. Hay and pils. Biscuit and stuff...

On tap at Joe Canals West Deptford.
Appearance: Clear amber body with a creamy head that lingers.
Aroma: Light lemon with floral notes.
Taste: Slight malts with a dry leaning feel, slightly bitter with some floral and lemon notes.
Palate: Medium bodied, lively carbonation.
Overall: This is okay, nothing I would buy again.
Draft at blue monk. Orange amber pour. Malt heavy, somewhat fruity, touch of earthy, very light peat. Nice alt

Draft at the brew pub. Pours clear copper with a small white head. The aroma Is very malty with mostly caramel, maybe a light smoke. The taste is lightly sweet and lightly malty as well. There is a slight hopliness. This is good but sticke and double sticke set a crazy expectation for the style.
Draft at the source. Clear golden color, thick white head, solid lacing. Aroma pf biscuity hay. Taste is similar.
On tap at Victory Brew Pub. Pours clear copper with two finger white head. Spruce, pepper, lemon, grass. Moderately bitter. A little salty. Somewhat acidic. Not bad.

Draft. Poured hazy brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate complex toasted balanced aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Moderate toasted complex flavor with a moderate bittersweet finish of average duration. Good drinkable brew.
Draft to taster. Looks solid; a transparent brownish-orange with off-white head. Smells and tastes of dough and malt. Average on the palate. Not my style.

On tap. Pours a mostly clear darker shade of orange, with a big, dense foamy cream-colored head, leaves good lace. Nose has some good earthy hops, chocolate malts, rich dark fruit characteristics. Light body. Smooth, light carbonation. Clean finish. Description is spot-on, it is impressing how easy to drink and refreshing this is, yet it still has a great flavor. Altbier has been a confusing style for me so far, because most of the ones Ive tried have been imperial versions, and each one tastes drastically different. This, I think, is an example of the style that makes sense, finally. Good chocolate, nutty flavors, light earth, little herbal. Light bitter / sweet taste. Good stuff, a really unique experience.
Sampled on tap pours a light amber with a white head. Aromas of yeast some grass and pine.  Flavor is bitter snd body is light.  Finishes bitter

Growler from JCs in WD.  Darkish amber body with a rocky, lacing beige head.  Nose is hoppy with light caramel, taste quite bitter and a little rubbery on the yeast side, thinnish caramel malt in the light body, a little toffee/cracker and big, big earth but no real sign of alcohol.  A winner in spite of its slights.

This poured a semi murky lighter brown color with an off white head. Aroma was caramel, grass, some toasted malt, and some biscut notes.  Flavor was suprisingly bitter for most altbiers, but completely balanced with the  doughy biscuty malt.  Pleasant experience and a great example for the style.

Tap at Victory, Downington PA - 27/05/12.
Clear chestnut brown with medium off-white head.
Malts, caramel, nuts, mild hops on the nose.
Nutty, bready taste, backed with a mild malt base, a little caramel and an earthy bitterness on the finish.
Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, easy drinking alt.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On tap at Victory.  Served in a sample glass. Pale caramel with some bread in the nose. A bit of earthy hops. Light body with a dry finish. Fairly bitter. Crisp.

Served on draft at Beer Run. Pours a clear copper color with a medium sized creamy white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of herbal hops and toasted mildly toffee malts. The taste is toasted toffee malts, the faintest hint of raisin, herbal and minty hops. Slight lingering bitterness, medium bodied, refreshing,

bit darker than festbier, more copper less orange, similar head of puffy cream islands atop small bubbled wisps. Muted nose is earthy, plum and clay with considerable grass. Flavor sweeter, some chocolate at front light hay as field bitterness through the finish, where strong bitterness couples with dry finish to accent mild-like malts, doughy but dark and rich.

Tap at Victory. Pour is clear tea amber. Off white head. Webby complete lacing. Nose is dense malty, spicy earth, small maple. Taste is sharp hoppiness, dense malt, maple, spice. Palate is perfect malt and hop balance. Rich, quenching, dense, loads of wheat bread crust and whole grain flour. Very delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep copper colored with a medium white head.  Aroma has nice rusty malts, toasty, citrus hops, a bit of sweetness, too.  Medium bodied. Sweet, toasty malts, medium citrus hops, herbal notes. Finish has a lingering sharp bitterness. really a great summer refresher.
Draft at Unos Hamilton.  Pours amber with a small head.  Taste is bitter and slightly sweet, moderate european style hops with a smaller malt balance.

Draft at Churchkey. Nose finds notes of almond, caramel, grassy hop, touches of pepper and herbal presence of sage and touches of rosemary. Flavor is similar but with more depth of profile, with nice hoppy bite on the finish. Smooth, drinkable. Nice stuff.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Poured dark amber with a large fluffy head. Tastes like a strong ale with a blend of light toasted bready wheat notes and dark burnt wheat flavors. Black pepper. Green banana. Tiny bit of sour funk. Medium body. Big hop bite. Charcoal lingers after the finish. Oddly refreshing.
Pours opaque brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is very malty...sweet.  flavor follows suit...tastes like mash...where are the hops?  Mouthfeel is medium/full with a grainy/malty finish.

Pours amber with a thin khaki head.  Aroma is nutty, caramel and bready.  Taste is sweet with a faint hint of bitters on the finish...very faint.  Smooth and easy to drink, somewhat flatter mouth feel then expected.
A great beer for a hot day.  Nutty but with some hop bitterness.  Very little aftertaste.  Pours amber with small white head.  Easy going down and light in alcohol.  Paired very well with the burger.
On tap at Victory. Poured an amber color with a small sized head. Floral, some earth, caramel, and some nuts.
Tap at Victory, tall pint glass. Pour is a dark amber with a fine head. Taste is a very bitter hop and malt. Feel is that of a med, Lager. Finish is clean crisp and bitter.
On tap at brewpub.  Pours a clear copper color with an aroma of bread, caramel, and toasted malt.  Toasted malt flavor with bread and some caramel.  Nice beer.

I was really impressed with this beer.  Didnt know what to fully expect with this one.  Nice mixture of spices, nuttiness, and a kick of hops. Had kind of a biscuit backbone.  It was highly carbonated and light bodied.  An even better session beer. I could of sat there all damn day and drank this one.

Tap at Maxs.  Pours a nice medium copper with lasting off white head and streaky lace.  Aroma is mineral, toast, light bready malts,, some caramelized malt, nutty and grassy green hops.  Flavor is light fruity and caramel, with herbal hops, slight mint with a good nutty chewy malt running through the middle and a the finish is crisp mineral, and medium tacky bitterness which I liked.  Nice.

On tap at the Blind Tigers Victory event.  Pours a clean clear light brown with a medium sized white head.  Crisp malt, lightly sweet.  Earthy malt with a touch of bitterness through it.  Long bitter grapefruit and toast on the finish.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Copper in color with a thick white head. Slightly bitter and hoppy aroma with some malts underneath. Very dry and bitter at the start of the flavor with a smooth and slightly corny malt middle. Very dry and bitter on the aftertaste.
On tap @ brewery.  Nice amber pour, attractive brewwith excellent compliment of Euro hops.  Not a styleI sample very often, very nice

On tap, at brewery.  Clear amber body with a small fizzt off-white head that fell to a wispy film.  Nicely fruity and toasty malts with some minimal hops and a touvh of crystal malt.  The flavor is fairly dry with some perfumy hops and toasty malts.  Some graininess as well.  Light to medium bodied, a little coarse in texture with fizzy carbonation.  Not bad, but not among the best.
Pours a dark amber with aroma and taste of malt and hops.  Smooth, slightly dry finish, closest thing I have had to the style over in the states.  Frequently see Ron and Bill drinking it.

Sampled on tap at Maxs in Baltimore.  Pours a totally clear, copper, orange amber with one ring of white head.  Smells like malts, like dried barley grains, crackers bread.  It honestly smells like my homebrewing mashtun.  Flavor is sweet, crisp, malty, lightly bready, non descriptive citrus fruits.  Finish is a little watery.
clear amber with decent head... sweeter than expected aroma, malty, minimal hoppiness... kind of a bland malt first flavor, somewhat sweet, with a thin watery finish... medium light body...

20100306 tap at brewpub. According to the bartender, this is new, not a rebadge. Menu says 5.1 abv, so this may warrant a new entry by someone in the know. Light bronze color with sturdy tan head. Aroma was soapy hops, white yeasty bread. Body was light, too light, with huge, aggressive eff that was more distracting than anything. Light bready and pepper notes to finish. Lingering hop floral notes. Again Im thinking that many of these beers are tasting the same.

Not a bad altbier, pretty average really, copper color, decent off-white head, malty nose with a slight tone of hops, very balanced body with a good combination of malt & hops, body was a bit too light though, overall a very drinkable & smooth session beer

I found this alt to be a bit weak all around. The color was a bit too light, the head was a bit too flat and the flavor lacked the bite I associate with alt. Having said that, it was still a very pleasant beer.

I like altbiers...I like Victory beers....and I like this beer.  Pours dark straw/amber with aroma and taste of malt, hopcit, and a smooth, slightly dry finish.  True to the German style, as with all Victory beers.  These guys are among the few Americans who are invited INTO Germany to make beer!

Poured a dark golden color with a thin off white head that left no lacing on the glass.  Earthy, sweet and citrusy aroma.  Grassy, citrus, German hop taste with a dry finish.  A pleasant bitter hoppiness, not unline orange peel.
the best example i know of compared to any german brands i have tried. these guys are not afraid to use malt and hops
A limited edition brew from Victory that is worth trying if you can find it.
Big grainy nose and a great subtle hop spicyness, that sneeks up on you. Compares well to the traditional ALTs from Germany.
